summary: Private equity firms, always on the lookout for the silver lining of even the grimmest cloud, have seen the recent spate of ransomware attacks as a boon to the cybersecurity sector. Today, WSJ Pro PE’s Laura Cooper brings news of the latest deal in the space: Bain Capital and Crosspoint Capital linking up for a $900 million investment in ExtraHop Networks Inc., a company that provides services to defend against ransomware and other threats. Next, Laura Kreutzer reports that SoftBank Group Corp. is leading a $90 million funding round for Whatfix Inc., a software maker that has seen its valuation triple since its investment round last year.

title: Wealth Gap Likely to Widen as Major Economies Power Recovery, World Bank Says

title: Commodity Price Surges Add to Inflation Fears
summary: Economists say China’s producer-price index, a gauge of factory-gate prices, could climb to its highest level since August 2008 on Wednesday amid rising commodity prices. Lumber, iron ore and copper prices have hit records. Corn, soybeans and wheat have jumped to their highest levels in eight years. Oil recently reached a two-year high. Central bankers must decide whether to keep looking past the increases, along with other signs of higher inflation, or move faster to cool demand through rate rises or other moves.

title: Is the Dollar’s Long Slide Coming to an End?
summary: The recovery-related forces that have pushed the greenback down over the past year may be almost spent.

title: A Commodities Crunch Caused by Stingy Capital Spending Has No Quick Fix

title: VC Daily: Startup M&A Value Spikes
summary: Merger-and-acquisition deal value for venture-backed startups has been on a tear this year. The value of such deals globally has surged 877% to roughly $238 billion through June 2 compared with the same period last year, according to data prepared by analytics provider Refinitiv. The number of these acquisitions rose 23% to 272 over the same period.

title: PE Daily: Alpine Seeks $1.7 Billion | Ackman SPAC Eyes Universal Music | State Senator Puts Pressure on PSERS
summary: As the first week of June comes to a close, the private-equity industry is showing no signs of a summer slowdown, either in fundraising or dealmaking. This morning, our own Preeti Singh has news of San Francisco-based Alpine Investors’ latest fundraising effort, while our colleagues at The Wall Street Journal report on what promises to be a record blank check deal for Universal Music. Finally, Preeti also has an update on the continued saga unfolding over an investigation into certain investments at Pennsylvania’s largest state pension system.

title: Fed’s Williams Says It’s Too Early to Reduce Bond Buying; Government Bond Yields Expected to Stay Low as Inflation Fears Ease
summary: Some Fed officials are shifting their view on the central bank’s $120 billion a month in bond purchases, saying it may soon be time to open talks on how to reduce them. John Williams, head of the New York Fed, isn’t among them. He said yesterday the U.S. economic recovery still needs to make more progress before the Fed should pare its purchases. “I just don’t think the time is now to take any actions,” he said. Today’s May jobs report will shed more light on the progress of the recovery. Meanwhile, investor worries about tighter policy from central banks have calmed. And India’s central bank said it would boost its bond-buying program.

title: PE Daily: Rhode Island Approves Hospital Deal | Mercato Raises $100 Million Restaurant Fund | Waterland Gets ESG Credit Line
summary: It’s officially June and the start of Pride Month. The private-equity industry for years has devoted time and resources to promoting gender and racial diversity among its ranks. But, it has devoted far less attention to promoting more inclusive work environments and policies for members of the gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender community. However, thanks partly to the efforts of forward-looking firms like KKR & Co., Blackstone Group and Carlyle Group, as well as advocacy groups like Out Leadership, the industry is slowly starting to close the gap, even though there is still much work to be done.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Hedge Fund Day-Trades AMC; Oil Servicer Files Bankruptcy Suit; Avadim Seeks Lender Sale; Kyrgyz Mine Placed In Bankruptcy
summary: After staring down bankruptcy last year, AMC Entertainment Holdings is riding a stunning rally fuelled by individual investors. A hedge-fund shareholder became a big beneficiary Tuesday, engaging in some rapid-fire day trading itself.

title: Brainard Says Fed Should Be Steady But Flexible; Kashkari Says Fed Has Tools to Battle Inflation; Investors’ Inflation Bet Loses Some Steam
summary: Federal Reserve governor Lael Brainard said the central bank should be prepared to adjust policy, depending on the data it reviews. Economic data released in the past few weeks have pointed to mounting inflationary pressures as the economy reopens, which Ms. Brainard attributed to temporary mismatches between supply and demand skewing data on both employment and inflation. Meanwhile, Minneapolis Fed leader Neel Kashkari said the Fed “has the tools to adjust interest rates to keep inflation in check and to prevent it from spiraling out of control.” And a key measure of investors’ inflation expectations has slipped in recent days, stirring debate over whether it has finally peaked after this year’s near-relentless climb.

title: PE Daily: Fin VC Seeks $300 Million for Two Funds | Mass PRIM Backs Emerging, Diverse Managers | White Deer Names New Leaders
summary: We have a full slate of news ahead of the long weekend, starting with a scoop from Preeti Singh and I on the fundraising plans of Fin Venture Capital. The firm, which focuses on fintech and was founded three years ago by the former head of SoFi Ventures, is seeking $300 million for two funds, one for early-stage and one for late-stage investments. Next, Preeti reports on Mass PRIM’s plans for an emerging-managers program to increase its allocation to diverse fund sponsors. In an interview, Massachusetts State Treasurer Deborah Goldberg, who chairs the $90 billion board, explains why the fund is moving to allocate at least 20% of its assets to diverse emerging managers. Finally, Luis Garcia reports that White Deer Energy is shifting to new leadership as it seeks to move beyond the oil and gas deals that had been the firm’s forte up to now.

summary: The Federal Reserve’s balance sheet stood at just over $4 trillion before the coronavirus pandemic struck the U.S. Now, it could be heading toward $9 trillion by 2023, according to a Federal Reserve Bank of New York report released Monday. The report comes as questions mount as to when the Fed will reduce its asset purchases, currently running at $120 billion a month to provide stimulus for the economy. Also on Monday, Fed governor Lael Brainard raised concerns about use of private moneys for consumer payments at a cryptocurrency industry.

title: Federal Reserve Minutes Telegraph Tapering Bond Purchases
summary: Federal Reserve officials want to begin planning for tapering the central bank’s bond-buying program, minutes from their policy meeting in April showed. There was general agreement among officials on the need to continue supporting the economy with near-zero interest rates and bond purchases. But the minutes also dropped the Fed’s first hint that policy makers could soon begin discussing a slowdown in the pace of its Treasury and mortgage-bond purchases, which currently total at least $120 billion a month. The minutes noted that many officials echoed Chairman Jerome Powell’s view that the Fed should give markets plenty of advance warning before it begins reducing the purchases.

title: Markets Decline Globally, and Fed Hints at a Policy Review
summary: U.S. stocks, commodities, overseas shares and bitcoin dropped in turbulent trading Wednesday as investors’ risk appetite diminished.

title: U.K. Polluters Face Higher Costs as Breakaway Carbon Market Goes Live

title: Summers Pans Fed Policy; Biden and Yellen Stump for Infrastructure Spending
summary: Lawrence Summers, Treasury secretary under former President Bill Clinton and one-time contender to become chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned Tuesday that the current monetary policy outlook invites trouble, arguing that “serenity is being projected with respect to inflation” by the Fed. Ultra-easy monetary policy amid massive government stimulus spending potentially sets the stage for a “vicious cycle” on the inflation front, according to Mr. Summers, who has also criticized the Biden’s administration’s economic policies in recent weeks. Meanwhile, President Biden and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen promoted his administration’s infrastructure and tax plans Tuesday. Speaking at a U.S. Chamber of Commerce event, Ms. Yellen sought to win support from business leaders, saying the plans will put U.S. companies on a better footing to compete overseas.

title: European Companies, Flush With Cash, Turn to Stock Buybacks
summary: This year has seen a slew of companies in Europe putting forward share repurchase programs, a trend that signals growing confidence among corporate leaders and marks a pivot in strategy in a region that has traditionally favored dividends.

Buyout fund deal makers may welcome that forecast, but sellers less so.

summary: Yesterday’s market selloff shows just how jittery people are. Another inflation signal like the one from the Labor Department on consumer prices could easily sow more havoc. But maybe the restoration of service on the Colonial Pipeline will help calm nerves. No doubt images of lines at filling stations and “Out of Gas” signs popping up in Virginia, Georgia and South Carolina brought back some evil memories of the 1970s for those old enough to remember.

title: Consumer Prices Jump, Casting Doubt on Fed’s View That Inflationary Pressures Will Fade
summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said he believes most of the recent acceleration in prices, underscored by the 4.2% increase in consumer prices in April from a year earlier, will prove transitory as the U.S. economy works through supply and demand mismatches that emerged during the pandemic. But some observers said the latest inflation figures show the Fed may have to abandon its plans to keep easy-money policies in place until the labor market is fully healed. “I think they are going to have to raise rates, for sure,” or risk the economy overheating, Pershing Square Capital Management Chief Executive Bill Ackman said at The Wall Street Journal’s Future of Everything Festival.

title: Fed Officials Hold Steady on Message That They Will Hold Policy Steady
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard and the presidents of the Atlanta, Philadelphia and St. Louis Fed banks stressed yesterday that the central bank isn’t in a hurry to change its accomodative policy stance. The recovery remains a work in progress, Philly Fed chief Patrick Harker said, noting that “Fed policy is going to hold steady.” It’s a sentiment that has also been expressed by a number of other Fed officials in recent days in a show of support for the central bank’s near-zero short-term rate target and its $120 billion a month in bond buying.

title: Stocks Slide on Inflation Data, Extending Decline
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 post their steepest three-day declines in nearly seven months, while a sharp rise in consumer prices heightened concerns that interest rates could be headed higher.

title: Few Signs of Recovery for U.S. Oil Production, OPEC Says
summary: American oil production is set to drop again this year, with the shale industry’s output showing few signs of recovery despite a broader pickup in economic activity, OPEC said.

title: Biden’s Not-So-Clean Energy Transition
summary: The International Energy Agency exposes the hidden environmental costs and infeasibility of going green.

title: Quantum Energy Begins Drive for New $4.5 Billion Pool
summary: Quantum Energy Partners has started raising $4.5 billion for its eighth energy-focused flagship strategy, betting that rising oil prices will help it win over investors after putting the campaign on hold last year, said people familiar with the matter.

title: Inflation Is Coming. Here's What To Do About It.
summary: There are useful strategies that can be put to work now as investors deal with the growing threat of rising prices.

title: Colonial Pipeline Shutdown Threatens to Magnify Gasoline-Price Surge
summary: A cyberattack disrupted the largest U.S. fuel conduit at the same time more drivers are preparing to travel after getting coronavirus vaccines.

title: Colonial Pipeline Attack Highlights Additional Obstacles
summary: Fuel prices are already high, for reasons unrelated to gasoline supply. A prolonged shutdown of Colonial’s line could make for an expensive summer for drivers.

title: Corn Is the Latest Commodity to Soar
summary: Corn has been one of the sharpest risers in the broad rally in raw materials that is prompting companies to boost prices for goods and fueling concern among investors that inflation could hobble the economic recovery.

title: Colorado Drillers to Combine, as Consolidation Continues in Oil Patch
summary: Bonanza Creek Energy and Extraction Oil & Gas are the latest to tie up, creating a $2.3 billion company.

title: BioNTech, Arch Capital, Freeport-McMoRan: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Technology shares were poised to decline after the bell.

title: Record Iron Ore Prices Have Rusty Underpinnings
summary: Politics and capacity constraints are behind the surge in iron ore prices over the past few days. Neither will necessarily play out how investors think.
